text: at Block Science on this idea of research he had done into a type of dynamical system called generalized dynamical systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And essentially dynamical systems usually are advanced by the application of a single specific rule.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So for instance, the logistic map where you just take x sub n plus one and it's equal to alpha times x sub n times one minus x sub n all in parentheses.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They advanced by a singular rule.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Whereas in generalized dynamical systems, these were created initially with the idea that you were dealing with systems where there would be some type of switch.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: or some type of input at a given point.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so you needed a way where not only were you applying a single rule, but you were actually responding to actions that were taken within the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And naturally that sort of branches out into the idea that there need to be agents that the system now has components that have agency.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So it's moving from a purely deterministic dynamical system
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: where the components proceed according to a completely pre-described mechanism and moving towards a system where the components have agency.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that naturally acts, that naturally intersects with the idea of agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So agents are, you know, multi-agent systems are a very vast area of research that are especially important in economics and biology and other places, any type of social system where agents interact.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I came to them via cellular automata.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But again, the agents there are cells who are
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: engaged in behavior that's mechanistic.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The cells in a cellular automaton don't have individual choice.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They follow the same rule, and yet you still see emergent behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So when you add in agency and the type of feedback loops that are emphasized in active inference, now you're going to see the possibility of different types of emergence.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: based on the choices that the agents make.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so there's a computational tool called CAD-CAD or computer aided design of complex adaptive dynamics
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: which is working with the CAD framework from engineering where you're using computer-aided design to work with mechanical systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But now you're using computer-aided design to look at complex systems according to a well-defined syntax that lets you define what happens at different stages of an interaction.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this connects to a type of economic model
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: called multi-agent influence diagrams which are a type of causal inference structure in economics that were introduced by color and milch and all three of these there are maps between these things i think of these as a mathematician sometimes i think in terms of category theory or categories
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For me, it was like there are obvious morphisms between these categories that they're not three distinct things that are just because it's not too hard to translate between the three different realizations of a system.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so I was exploring that and playing with it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It improved my understanding of CADCAD a lot.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I appreciated the elegance of CADCAD a lot more as a tool after kind of translating it into terms that my brain was more comfortable with.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But yeah, it's a good series of workshops.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I enjoyed doing it and I don't think I'm happy to get feedback on from people and engage in conversations with people about.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I think the most interesting thing for me
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: is that as soon as we now have structure, we can gain understanding through that structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the point of introducing this notation is not to just look more formal, but if we have something and we say, oh, this is a directed graph, this is a labeled directed graph, like Dr. Zargum drew that image,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so he has a label-directed graph with subgraph components.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Well, now there are lots of systems that have a label-directed graph with subgraph components.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we know how to do things like add an edge, add a node, change a label.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We know these different structures and how we can study them.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: with these parameters like families of structures right and that's kind of where my brain is drawn i my neurotype is such that i tend to get overwhelmed with immense complexity at once and personally the research journeys where i've been the most successful were the ones where i could find a starting place and identify some specific parameters to kind of tune the knobs on
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so like giving this type of problem, this type of structure gives us an entry point where, from my perspective, now not only do we understand it better and translate it to ourselves better and can communicate it with interested non-technicians better,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: communicate it amongst ourselves better but also we can look at specific aspects of the structure to see how specific structures behave in ways that we might be able to predict and this is this is the starting point of a lot of the complex systems research for instance the game of life when john conway was designing the game of life cellular automaton
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: He tried several different rules just guessing and checking to see which ones might have which parameter values for birth and death might lead to interesting configurations.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01
